editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: ANSELM, JOHN OF DAMASCUS; S. XIV in.

msItem.note: On fol. iiiv are notes of s. xiv and xv on Anselm’s works, including two tables of contents, s. xiv, covering the works of Anselm and those that follow respectively. The second indicates that Bede, De Natura Rerum, is now missing from the end. According to Thomas James (see below), preceding this was another lost item which he describes as ‘Sententiae Io. Armachani’ (perhaps meaning art. 13).
On fol. iv is a paragraph in a hand of s. xv: ‘Deo suplica, parentes ama, cognatos cole, mundus esto, stude agere quod iustum est...’.

On f. ivv is a table of contents in a distinctive large square hand, s. xiv in., probably that of John Grandisson, bishop of Exeter 1327–1369. Against it the same or a similar hand has written critical comments: ‘Corruptissime scriptum’, ‘Scriptum falsissime’, ‘Pessime scriptum’.

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Monologion
msItem.incipit: Quidam fratres me sepe studioseque precati sunt
msItem.explicit: solus Deus ineffabiliter trinus et unus

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Proslogion
msItem.incipit: Postquam opusculum quoddam uelud exemplum medicandi
msItem.explicit: donec intrem in gaudium Domini mei qui ...

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Contra Insipientem
msItem.incipit: Ergo domine qui das fidei intellectum

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Concordia Praescientiae et Praedestinationis
msItem.rubric: Liber de concordia prescientie predestinacionis et gratie libero arbitrio

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Veritate
msItem.rubric: Incipit prefacio beati Anselmi in opus subditum
msItem.incipit: Tres tractatus pertinentes ad studium sacre scripture

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Libero Arbitrio
msItem.incipit: Quoniam liberum arbitrium uidetur repugnare gratie

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Casu Diaboli
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt capitula in tractatum Anselmi de casu dyaboli
msItem.incipit: Illud apostoli Quid habes quod non accepisti
msItem.explicit: et uti potestate loquendi. Explicit. R.

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Grammatico
msItem.incipit: De gramatico peto ut me certum facias

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Cur Deus Homo
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus in Cur Deus homo
msItem.explicit: Deo non nobis attribuere debemus qui ...

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: De Conceptu Virginali
msItem.incipit: Cum in omnibus religiose tue uoluntati

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Epist. 414
msItem.rubric: Anselmus Dei gratia Dorobernensis archiepiscopus dilectis sororibus et sacris uirginibus salutem et benedictionem
msItem.incipit: F. k. omnis actio laudabilis seu reprehensibilis

msItem.author: John of Damascus
msItem.title: De Fide Orthodoxa
msItem.rubric: Iohannis Damasceni qui Cumansur liber incipit in quo est tradicio certa orthodoxe fidei capitulis diuisa centum a Burgundione iudice ciue Pisano de Greco in Latinum domino tercio Eugenio bone memorie papa translatus
msItem.note: ed. E. M. Buytaert (St Bonaventure, NY, 1955), pp. 1–135.

msItem.title: Tract on the cardinal virtues
msItem.rubric: Incipit quidam paruus tractatus de uirtutibus cardinalibus
msItem.incipit: Plotinus inter philosophie professores cum Platone princeps in libro de uirtutibus
msItem.note: Bloomfield 3933, this copy only. fol. 191 is covered with notes, mainly in pencil, except for a five-line recipe: ‘R. amigdalas amaras et ter’ eas minutissime …’ , s. xv in. fols. 191v–2v blank.
Throughout is early marginal annotation, some of it probably in the same hand as the table of contents on fol. iiiv.

supportDesc.extent:
198 leaves (iv + 194) 265 185
200 135
The edges heavily retrimmed, affecting marginalia, and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: a bifolium at each end, 1–712, 86, 9–1612, 174; catchwords.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with pencil in 2 cols of 36 lines.

handDesc.handNote: A large and formal English gothic rotunda bookhand.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue flourished initials with partial borders; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; running heads in large capitals in the colours; red or blue initials and paraphs for capitula.

physDesc.additions: Marginal corrections and annotation, mainly in a single early hand.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii; sewn on six bands; formerly chained from the usual position. fol. i has the mark of a chain-staple near the foot of the foredge; f. 192 has the mark of a brass one in the middle of the foot.

physDesc.accMat: fols. i-ii, 193–4 are paper binding leaves, the outermost from a printed book, s. xvi (running heads ‘De cultu Dei externo’, ‘De ymaginibus’).

history.provenance: On fol. iv‘prec ii. marcas’, ‘Liber correctus est per totum’, and a large early press mark ‘F 2m’.
history.acquisition: James no. 231, and therefore at the College before 1600. Loose in the book, probably once pasted inside the front board, is a sheet of paper with a table of contents and ‘N. 4. 6. Art:’, s. xvii, canc. and replaced with ‘C. 1. 6 (XLV)’ in red. On fol. iii is ‘C. 1. 6’ twice, in red ink and pencil. ‘6’ is inked on the foredge. On fol. iiivis the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
